Guys, I figured out how it works

A magical property called




The wind.

For the anti-"soccer" purists:  the name football was used as far back as the Middle Ages for what is now called "mob football," which had no rules and involved two large groups of people trying to move the ball into goals a long distance apart.  Nothing prevented you from using your hands and indeed carrying the ball (other than the fact that you might get trampled by a mob of opponents).  The "foot" part refers to the fact that you played on your feet and not on horseback - a very important distinction at that time, as it marked football as a game for the masses and not the equestrian elite.  So, no, "football" does not actually mean a game dominated by kicking.  It just worked out that way in Association football/FIFA football/soccer - a happy verbal accident.

Thank you, that was very cool. I didn't know about the smooth ball effect before.

Some of the best Magnus effect results are with a cricket ball. Most balls are completely symetrical, but a cricket ball is not. It has a raised seem dividing it into two hemispheres. I guess the rubber band on the shiny ball has a similar effect. Cricketers shine one side and let the other get rough. That way you can get it to curve either way depending on which way up you hold it and how fast you get it to spin. You can also effect the flight of the ball if you spin it round a horizontal axis. This is also used by baseball pitchers to make the ball stay up or dip depending on which way it is spun. I've read some interesting Ph. D thesis(es?) about the Magnus effect in ball games.

So in the simple magnus effect, the boundary layer is turbulent everywhere?
So in the simple magnus effect, the boundary layer is turbulent everywhere?

That brings another question to my mind. Why does the increase in the velocity of the air on the bottom change the boundary layer from laminar to turbulent? Even at a higher velocity, the ball is still smooth, and velocity is only relative, isn't it? Especially when viewed in light of all the possible velocities available in the universe, from infinitely slow (you can always be slower, I think - it's like the object that moves half the distance to its goal with every step, and so it will never get there; so you can always cut your speed in half and never stop) to the speed of light, potentially. The relationship between the velocities of both sides of the ball is virtually nothing. Or the same for the water? Why is it laminar at a lower volume than a higher as it leaves the faucet? Don't all forces increase or decrease evenly (Not sure I worded that right)? For example: Why does traffic on the freeway, assuming no bottlenecks on the freeway such as decreasing numbers of lanes or intersections, slow to a crawl when there is more of it? It's obviously drivers behaving differently in terms of speed, changing lanes etc, each with their own mind as they make decisions. Theoretically bumper to bumper traffic could travel at hundreds of miles per hour or more if every driver is going the exact same speed - no turbulence. But the air molecules don't have minds, they just all behave the same way.

[03:56] Wrong: airplane wings rely on laminar flow over the top because laminar sticks;
But, driven, golfballs, contacting the driver below, first, are backspun (unlike Hollywood shows) and with dimples have turbulent flow that results in a 'popup' (positive Magnus Effect) but only as the ball slows about halfway down the fairway from the initial strike.

What really helps me is the mathematical representation. The Magnus effect is equal to w x v (w is omega). Also something interesting to explain turbulent vs laminar flow is the dimples on a golfball. They are designed to create an immediate turbulent boundary layer to reduce the wake behind the ball thus reducing the overall drag force and allowing it to fly father. It is really counter intuitive that increasing the fiction of the air passing over the ball would decrease the drag but that is the effect the wake can have.

I didn't play soccer much growing up but I played A LOT of baseball. Have you ever heard of a knuckle ball in baseball? It's when you throw the ball with almost no spin and the ball will actually wobble. The faster you throw it, the more it "wobbles." I've always wondered how the magnus effect plays a part in determining which direction the ball will move. Also, I love your videos!

You attribute the change in direction/momentum of the streamline as to the cause of the change in the ball's trajectory. I don't really think that is correct and here is an example of why; an airfoil.

The principle as you see which causes the ball to turn is the same which gives an airfoil lift, which is a pressure differential caused by the curvature of the ball and the fluid flowing over it's surface. This causes a lower static pressure on the top side than the bottom which causes the ball to curve. The pressure differential itself is caused due to the dynamic pressure at the top of the ball to be higher than the bottom which then causes the static pressure at the top of the ball to be lower than the bottom where static pressure is the main cause of the direction change of the ball since that is the only macroscopic force (with enough magnitude to impact the trajectory) that acts perpendicular to the ball's surface (where dynamic pressure acts parallel to the surface of the ball in this case, think of the ram effect in ramjets as an analogy). Also, it makes sense that the dynamic pressure at the top would be higher since along a streamline, the particles would experience a greater positive acceleration due to the curvature of the ball which causes a larger velocity. (also an Aerospace student here :-) woot woot!!! )

Also, for the smooth bouncy ball, I can't say I agree with the explanation once again because we can't visually confirm the direction in which the ball spins. If my above theory is correct, if you were to find a way to see which way the ball spins, I would say clockwise! Just because you hit the ball the same way doesn't necessarily mean that it will spin and therefore react the same way! I hope you try this out!!! :)

Btw, my above explanation can also be used to explain why top-spin in tennis makes a ball curve downwards or putting a back-spin on a tennis ball will make it travel farther since once again, it's the same train of logic with dynamic/static change while stagnation pressure remains constant
